description: From Middle English lot, from Old English hlot (“portion, choice, decision”), from Proto-Germanic *hlutą.
Cognate with North Frisian lod, Saterland Frisian Lot, West Frisian lot, Dutch lot, French lot, German Low German Lott, Middle High German luz. Doublet of lotto. Related also to German Los.

entries.meaning: A large quantity or number; a great deal.
examples: to spend a lot of money

entries.meaning: A separate portion; a number of things taken collectively.
One or more items auctioned or sold as a unit, separate from other items.
(informal) A number of people taken collectively.
A distinct portion or plot of land, usually smaller than a field.
examples: a building lot in a city

entries.meaning: That which happens without human design or forethought.
examples: Synonyms: chance, accident, destiny, fate, fortune

entries.meaning: Anything (as a die, pebble, ball, or slip of paper) used in determining a question by chance, or without human choice or will.
The part, or fate, that falls to one, as it were, by chance, or without one's planning.
examples: We seem to be made to suffer. It's our lot in life.
Archons served only for one year and, since 487/6, they were chosen by lot. Generals, on the other hand, were chosen by direct election and could be reelected without limit.

entries.meaning: (definite, the lot) All members of a set; everything.
examples: The table was loaded with food, but by evening there was nothing but crumbs; we had eaten the lot.
If I were in charge, I'd fire the lot of them.

entries.meaning: (historical) An old unit of weight used in many European countries from the Middle Ages, often defined as 1/30 or 1/32 of a (local) pound.

verbs.description: lot (third-person singular simple present lots, present participle lotting, simple past and past participle lotted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, dated) To allot; to sort; to apportion.
(US, informal, dated) To count or reckon (on or upon).
